This recipe is delicious. To reply to TMCLARTY, who said, "I thought the taste of this was rather odd... it tasted way too tangy/mustardy. I didn't have any honey, so I used honey dijon mustard... but I probably wouldn't make it again. Sorry."
All I can say is, please do NOT review recipes if you do not follow the recipe. This isn't fair. If you didn't use any honey and substituted more mustard in place of it, of course it tasted odd and way too mustardy. You didn't follow the recipe. Shame on you for leaving a bad review when you didn't use the correct ingredients called for in the recipe! Please, from now on, don't leave a review unless you followed the recipe.

text:
After reading all the rave reviews on this dish I decided to make it for my husband's birthday. Even though it looked amazing this is possibly the WORST recipe I have ever used for salmon. Don't bother wasting your ingredients. It is bland bland bland. I used an expensive salmon fillet which was more or less wasted and great pecans that could have been put to better use. Next time I will stick to my tried and tested recipe: a 1/4 cup white wine, some freshly squeezed lemon juice, salmon steaks or fillets, 1 tsp dried basil and 1 tsp dried oregano and freshly minced garlic, salt & pepper to taste. Cover and poach it for about 15 minutes top with a splash of extra virgin olive oil and it's the tastiest salmon you'll ever eat.

text:
Both my husband and myself absolutely love this recipe.  We have found that it works best if you skin the salmon and then coat all sides of it, it augments the flavor all around.  Also, the honey-mustard-butter coating makes A LOT.  You can generally halve it without too much trouble.

text:
PLEASE ignore the review below that called this the "worst" recipe. It isn't the least bit bland, but if you like more spice you can easily add a bit of cayenne or red pepper to taste. My family and I have been enjoying this recipe for years. I do use cornbread crumbs instead of breadcrumbs when I have them on hand -- just freeze a piece of cornbread if you have any left over, or use those new cornbread crackers I've seen in the grocery store. Serve with a sweet corn and black bean salad, fresh buttered green beans and chocolate pudding cake with vanilla ice cream and you have a stellar meal.

text:
Wow, this is a heck of way to serve salmon. I made this this evening and it came out great. I didn't "brush each salmon fillet lightly" though. Instead I spread the honey butter dijon sauce on rather thickly by letting the butter sauce start to harden up a bit before brushing it on. For the bread crumb topping, I put the pecans in a zip lock baggy and pounded them with a rolling pin until they were sort of the consistency of rough ground coffee and I chopped the parsley pretty fine too. Then I used the topping generously but not excessively. Very flavorful. Very easy to make. A definite keeper.

text:
Two thumbs up! This is, hands-down, one of the best recipes I've got from this site. I can't believe that other reviewers aren't drooling over it as much as we are! I've cooked a lot of salmon and this is one great recipe. It was absolutely delicious and very simple to make. Instead of breadcrumbs I used crushed bruschetta, although any sort of crackers would work quite nicely. I used a 1/2 cup of butter since I love saucey sauces. I skipped the nuts since I didn't have any on hand - tastes just fine without them. Instead of fresh parsley I used 1 teaspoon dried. I loved having extra sauce and I served it at the table so people could help themselves. Yum!!!!

text:
I just wanted to comment on some of the negative reviews for this recipe... I have been making a variation of this recipe for years (just the honey & dijon by itself with a little salt & pepper baked - a little healthier without the crumbs and nuts for those watching carbs) and it the compliment of the honey/dijon with the salmon is outstanding!  That said, I think the people that didn't like this recipe are looking for more of a salmon-y taste.  This recipe balances out the extreme fishiness of salmon (a turn-off for many people, myself included) and, while extremely delicious for those of use that appreciate it, it can definitely be a disappointment if you are looking for a real salmon-y flavor.  If that is what you are interested in, stick with the normal white wine & lemon recipe.  If you love milder fish and dislike the real fishy taste of salmon, this is DEFINITELY the recipe for you!

It was great... the first time I made this I didn't have peacans so I used Almonds and that was very good, but I figured the second time I'd follow the directions completely so I made it with the Peacans and it was outstanding.  I would say that this recipe is for people who like nuts and nice crunchyness to complement otherwise a delicate meal.  This recipe also allows for room to play with the amount of spicyness by using more, less, or different strengths/types of mustard.  I'm giving it an A.

I used Progresso Italian Bread Crumbs which I added some melted butter to, to make a nice crumbly mixture, as well as additional parsley.  When it was done, I squeezed fresh lemon juice over the top.  EVERYONE HERE LOVED IT!!!!!!!!!!  Served it w/ a salad and some roasted baby carrots and it was GREAT!  Will make this again!!!!!!!!

Portia & Luis

text:
I don't like salmon.  Luis loved this recipe.  I am looking forward to making it for him again.  He liked it so much that he started eating it before his lunch time.  He had to restrain himself from eating it all.  

2/11/2011
I made this for Luis again.  Central Market had Yukon 
Keta salmon for $8.49/lb which was a sale price.  (8) fillets cost $22.92.  I laid out all the ingredients and measuring cups to make sure that we had everything.  I had Organic Dijon mustard and chopped pecans left over from the last time i made this.  I follow the advice of others and only used (1) Tbsp of honey each time.  I used Italian seasoned Progresso bread crumbs.  I had to buy fresh Italian flat leaf parsley and salmon from Central Market.  I spread the thick honey mustard sauce on w/ a spatula onto each fillet, then used tongs to take it out of this goo, then laid it into a 4 Qt Oxo bowl of the bread crumb mixture and spooned and patted the crumbs over the fillets, then used the tongs to put each fillet into (2) different cast iron skillets that had been oiled.  I cooked the fillets approx (12) minutes b/c our gas oven runs hot and does not have temperature control.  Since the cast iron skillets hold the heat and the food continues to cook this was enuf time.  I woke Luis up to eat the salmon and he really enjoyed it.  I wish I liked salmon, but I love fixing it for Luis:) This is a good lunch dish for Luis.  He never brings it back home, unlike the Tuna casserole dish.

userID:

Display Name:
Savateuse
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/375655.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The best advice I can give you is TASTE the honey mustard mixture before you spread it on your fish, if you don't like it there, you won't like it on the fish so adjust it accordingly, add cracked black pepper, more honey, try whole grain mustard, adjust it until it appeals to you, then you know you will enjoy it on the fish.  I know the recipe says lightly but I smeared it on a little heavier.      I also opted or more pecans than breadcrumbs, I don't like "fillers" when I can avoid them.  Don't go out and buy breadcrumbs, if you have a food processor on your counter, use it! Grab a chunk of that baguette in your fridge and pulse it to crumbs, I used half a buttermilk biscuit left over for lunch and then chopped pecans, pulsed it in the processor to a coarse meal.        You can also substitute walnuts for this as well and it would be good.      For using frozen salmon filets instead of fresh, thaw your filets in cold water until pliable, dry them off with a paper towel and continue on with the recipe normally.     I also suggest making a little extra of the dijon honey spread, even after smearing it on liberally, the flavor really didn't come out in the fish, a drizzle over the top of the finished filet or a little puddle next to it is a good addition.   If you have extra beyond that, if you cut it with a bit of cider vinegar turning it to a dressing its a nice accompaniment tossed with a little fresh baby spinach.

text:
This was WONDERFUL! I Love salmon, butusually eat it grilled cause I hate the fishiness of baked fish. This recipie changed my view on baking fish, it was so tender and delicious I could have eaten 5 more pounds of it. I didnt use pecans because I hate nuts, so i added 2 cloves of garlic instead. I also used a mix of dijon and horseradish dijon, it gave it a nice flavor. I will be making this dish again I can promise you that!!!:::ON A SIDE NOTE::: I Eat this dish alot. 90% of my salmon i make this way, but the more I eat it the more i realize that 1 1/2 Tablespoons of honey is TOO much, i suggest about 1 or LESS. My; and im sure your guests would agree that less sweet is better but still 5 stars!

text:
Fantastic!  Thanks, Arnie!  I took the advice of other reviewers and made these modifications, and it came out perfect:  season the filets with salt & pepper prior to adding the mustard/honey mixture, painted the sauce on thickly by allowing it to firm a bit first, marinated it in the brushed-on sauce for 2 hours, & added a little olive oil to the breadcrumb mixture to get it brown and crispy.  Served it with rice that had a vegetable soup mix cooked in with it.  My family loved it!

dateLastModified:

userID:
901386
Display Name:
SABLEONE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
1Use a good salmon such as Alaskan or Coho. 2) To insure not to much mustard flavor, add the mustard (to taste) to the honey and then add it to the butter. 3) To control the consistency of the coating, stir the bread into the butter - mustard - honey mixture. Then add the parsley and nuts. 4) If you are baking a thicker fillet of salmon, you can insure a more even baking by first sauting the salmon for a minute or two in a skilet. (Hopefuly the skin will stick to the skillet and can be discarded.) Put the salmon in the baking pan, add the topping and put the salmon in the oven to finish. 5)I prefer to skin the salmon. If your salmon is frozen, you can lift one corner of the skin from the salmon filet and pull and the skin will easily be removed with no waste.

Ahh, now this is my kind of recipe.  It is soo easy to make and the taste is quite divine.  One thing I have done to make it even easier is make a big batch of the dry ingredients. This is one of my all time favorite recipes.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/622296.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious! I generally don't care for salmon but my husband really likes it so I have been managing to choke it down once or twice per week for a while now. Dreading tonight's meal, I searched at the last minute for something different from the typical lemon dill (yuck), maple (ick), or white wine-y (bleh) types of prep we're used to and found this recipe. I followed it pretty much as written - except used slivered almonds for pecans - but did take one reviewer's advice and let the honey/mustard mixture cool before slathering it on all sides of the fillet (I removed the skin first as also suggested)rather than just brushing it lightly on top. I also toasted panko crumbs and almonds in a skillet with a few drops of olive oil before adding the parsley and sprinkling them liberally on the fillets to make them super-crunchy. I actually enjoyed my salmon dinner tonight for the very first time! My husband loved it and said he wouldn't mind if I make it this way from now on, yay! The flavor is delicate, but really, really good! I had some mustard mix left over so I tossed my steamed green beans with it, which was also super delicious. Five stars!

userID:
15209755
Display Name:
Peter G
isPro:
False

1
favoritesCount:
14

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually cook for two people, my wife and me. So first thing is to reduce the recipe. I buy about 2/3 pound King or Coho. Stay away from the farmed Atlantic Frankenfish, if you don't use good fish, no recipe will fix it. I use 1 tbl each butter, honey and dijon mustard. IMO, parsley is pretty much a tasteless garnish. I substituted about 1/2 tsp dried dill which is super with fish and salmon in particular. Also added a generous amount of fresh ground pepper. I had no pecans (I'm sure dilish) so I used slivered almonds, a bit more crisp than pecans, but also very tasty. I used garlic herbed bread crumbs. Finally, I baked for about 18 minutes at 400 degrees. Still moist and firm but just beginning to flake. I've made this 3 times now and I'll make it again. Tastes great and easy to make.

This recipe was SO good that I printed out a copy and framed it to hang on my wall next to pictures of my children. Then I printed ANOTHER copy of this recipe and bought a wallet so that I could carry it around to show everyone I meet that I have a new best friend and when they wouldn't listen to me I shoved the recipe in their face and screamed "LOOK AT IT! IT'S BEAUTIFUL!! LOOOOK AT IT!!" Seriously though, I have made recipes from this site for a few years and I never felt compelled to write a review until now. Besides omitting the pecans ( I didn't have any) I followed the recipe to the T. It was by far the best salmon I have ever tasted and my family loved it too. For those that didn't like it and felt the need to give a bad review... I have some advice: Have someone who knows how to cook make it for you!

Display Name:
Emily Perlman
isPro:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We absolutely loved it! My fiancÃ© said it was the best salmon he'd ever had, and went back for seconds. He ate so much salmon that he didn't have room for ice cream, which is a first! 

This will become a staple in our house, since it was not only delicious but was so easy to prepare.  I actually added salt & pepper to the bread crumb mixture, which worked well. 

The honey mustard sauce has a nice tang (I only spread a thin layer on the top so it wasn't overpowering), and the bread crumbs gave the fish a good crunch. The pecans were an interesting addition (and one I never would have thought of; might also try with almonds or macadamia nuts sometime), and the fresh parsley was great (although in a pinch, dried parsley would probably work too).

I served it with wild rice and oven-roasted asparagus, and voilÃ¡ - a gourmet meal on a Tuesday night!

text:
This recipe was something you would find at a fine restaurant from a gourmet chef. I've become so sick to death of lemon salmon, that I wanted to try something new, and am SO glad I did. This is a completely unique flavor, so if your just looking for a "different" lemon salmon recipe, this is NOT for you. Sweet, tangy, crunchy, and delicious. The first bite caught me off guard, but after a few more, I couldn't get enough. If you are wanting more bang with the spices, add some cayenne, but I honestly thought the flavors were amazing without it.

text:
This was Fantastic and super easy!!! I made this last night and converted my Boyfriend to being a Salmon Lover with it! I used one very large filet with the skin still on instead of the smaller filets (allow extra cooking time for a large filet) and it served 3 people with plenty of leftovers. The Honey Dijon sauce adds a nice sweetness and the Breadcrumb Pecan mixture adds a wonderful, nutty crunch!! Simply Divine! You can also play around and amp up the spice level to suit your taste with some pepper or a spicier mustard. I will most definitely be making this again!!!!

text:
I've been using this recipe for years.  It was the first recipe I saved on All Recipes.  I use it so often, especially for company, that it became a joke with my friends and family!  Everyone I've fed this recipe too has absolutely loved it.  No changes.  No substitutions.  This recipe is perfectly balanced and delicious.  My only tip is to not overcook the salmon.  I prefer my salmon medium rare, and having the inside only barely cooked makes the dish even more divine.  Thanks, Esmee!  Your recipe has made me a star!

text:
I used salmon trout instead of salmon. It's cheaper. I used honey dijon, but also used honey. And as suggested by some reviewers, i poured all the sauce on the fish and them sprinkled the bread crumbs on top to absorb it. I thought it gave the fish more flavor rather than just brushing it on. The pecans were awesome. My only complaint is that the crust started burning a bit, i'd suggest placing a foil on top of the fish, so that it cooks, but not burn. You can remove the foil near the end so the crust can turn golden brown. I loved this recipe!

text:
This was AMAZING!!! My boyfriend and I loved it! I am not a very big mustard eater but this was so good. I used a large 1lb salmon filet and did not cut it up when cooking. Without any dijon on hand I used 2 tbsp whole grain mustard from central market and 1 tbsp honey mustard. Everything else I kept the same. I spread this on thick then sprinkled the bread crumbs over the salmon leaving out the nuts. Baked for 10 mins then broiled for additional 3 mins to get the crust crispy. Excellent! Served with long grain wild rice.

text:
Good, simple recipe to prepare quickly. I didn't have to buy any special ingredients, which I liked. Had everything on hand (sub'd walnuts instead of pecans, and panko instead of regular bread crumbs) The dijon wasn't overpowering, and when combined with the honey, you get a very nice flavor. I've also omitted the bread crumbs altogether before and served the salmon on ciabatta bread as a delicious sandwich, or on top of a salad. Great any way you have it.

text:
We love salmon and this was different, but we liked it. No pecans, but had sesame seeds and used them instead, were good. Mine took a bit longer to cook, but had big fillets.
Update 9-2011, This first review was done in 2007 and we've made this way too many times to count since. I do now keep a bag of pecans in my freezer just for this recipe. The pecans really do give this a great flavor. I still follow the recipe exactly as written, but do pour the marinade completely over the fish and let is sit for about thirty minutes before cooking. I try to always use fresh parsley and Italian bread crumbs. I do always line my pan with foil for easy clean up. I can't believe after all these years of making this dish, I've never taken a photo of it. So I did this time and will add it later. Thank you Esmee for a really tasty dish that we've enjoyed for years now.

text:
I've been using this recipe for the last few years; it's definitely a family favorite, and great on a variety of occasions. Best of all, I can make it using a total of 2 bowls and one baking dish. Easy clean up!!!!! Out of all the salmon recipes I've tried, I like this one the best because the salmon can really shine through all the other ingredients, rather than be masked by them. The breadcrumbs and pecans give it a very nice texture as well (I've also used walnuts and pistachios and they taste great too!). I sometimes like to add balsamic vinegar to the mix to give it a little extra kick, but most of the time it is great on its own. A squeeze of lemon right when it comes out of the oven can be the perfect touch. I like to make a rice pilaf or wild rice with lemon and asparagus on the side--my favorite accompaniments for this type of dish.

text:
Very nice salmon recipe that would be good for an everyday or company meal. A good change from a fish that can get dull quickly. Very easy to make. The sauce is more than needed, you'll have leftovers. No salt and pepper needed if you use seasoned breadcrumbs. Taking the feedback from others, I went light on the breadcrumbs, heavy on the pecans, and topped the fish only for the last 6 minutes. Worked out perfectly.

text:
This recipe has potential, but I was dissapointed with how it turned out.  The top turned out soggy and yet dry at the same time, but the overall flavor was good.  I think some of the butter in the sauce should be reserved and drizzled on top of the salmon before baking to crunch it up, which is what I'll try next time.  If that doesn't fix the problem then I won't be making this again.  UPDATE: I tried drizzling the melted butter on top and it still didn't fix it.  Too bad, since the flavors are good, but I can't get past the texture.  Goodbye Baked Dijon Salmon.

text:
This is a great recipe!!!!!  This is my first time cooking and eating fresh salmon and I can't believe how well this turned out.  I read the reviews and was a bit worried that I had chosen the wrong recipe to serve to my mum and brother, but it was a huge success.  Even my brother liked it and he won't eat anything that looks funny.  There is nothing you could do to make this better.  I didn't find the breadcrumbs became soggy and the dijon mustard (I used a brand that we have here in Australia, Keen's) was just great.  My parents are usually of the opinion that seafood of any kind is too expensive unless it's Christmas lunch, certainly too expensive for normal dinner with the family, but my mum said that this recipe made the cost of the salmon well worth it.  Also very filling.  Everyone who likes fish should try it.

My family loves this.  The only thing I do differently is something I learned from a chef.  Don't preheat the oven.  Put the salmon in a cold oven, turn it on to 400 and cook 25 minutes.  Perfect every time.

We followed the recipe as instructed.  The baking time is perfect and we all even like the topping on the fish.  The issue was with the honey mustard mixture.  It would be great for other meats, but it overwhelms the salmon flavor with sweetness, & makes for an odd combination.  If you eat salmon regularly, you know that salmon is a hard flavor to cover up.

text:
Absolutely delicious, even with all the substitutions I made. Didn't have Dijon mustard, used Spicy Brown instead. Didn't have pecans, so I left them out. Didn't have fresh parsley, used dried instead. The sweet, tangy bread topping compliments a rich, buttery fish very nicely. I served with lemon basmati rice (recipe also found on this site), and steamed broccoli in salted butter. We'll definitely be making this again.

country:

text:
I have made this recipe several times, and no matter what kind of tweaking I do, it's still fabulous. I have 4 kids -- a 7-yr-old boy and 16-yr-old triplets (a boy and 2 girls). All but my 16 yr old son have declared themselves salmon haters. (But we live outside of New Orleans, so of course they all like crawfish!) Anyway, this recipe toned their pipes down. I bought a 1.7 lb salmon fillet at Fresh Market, and I had to fight to keep a couple of scraps for my husband. I didn't have pecans -- though I have used them with this recipe in the past and they're great -- and I used plain panko instead of the breadcrumbs. I added a touch of soy sauce and a bit of brown sugar, put the broiler on for the last 2-3 minutes and the salmon caramelized beautifully. I served with rice and a store-bought Asian salad. Fantastic, easy meal. Thank you, Esmee!

text:
Excellent recipe!  I have made this twice.  The first time I followed the recipe almost exactly, the only changes being that I used some panco bread crumbs along with regular breadcrumbs and I didn't have fresh parsley so I used parsley flakes.  The 2nd time, I only used 2 tablespoons Dijon and my husband ranked this as one of the best things I've ever made!  I reduced the mustard to 2 tablespoons (as a personal preference as mustard has never been a favorite of mine).  Quick, easy, delicious and healthy -- all of the things I look for in a weekday meal!  Don't shy away from this one!

Display Name:
gayla

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
BEST baked salmon I've ever tasted.  I'm not usually much of a fan of baked salmon, but wind up having it once a month or so and dreading the leftovers.  Not with this recipe!  It took away the super "fishy" taste and replaced it with wonderful flavor.  I did make a few changes - mostly because I didn't have any honey or pecans.  I simply left the pecans out and don't think I will use them next time, either; they just don't appeal to me in a salmon recipe.  For the honey, I substituted honey dijon mustard and a spoonful of brown sugar.  It worked very well.  I also only cooked two large portions of fish, but kept the sauce amount constant, except that I actually used even more butter than the full recipe calls for.  Instead of just slathering it on right before cooking, I let my salmon sit in the sauce about half an hour - I don't know that it really made any difference, but it also didn't hurt.  And, as mentioned above, I used more the twice what was called for.  I also breaded both sides of my salmon (skin removed) quite heavily.  It was delicious!!!

text:
This recipe is amazing! It took me a total of 20 minutes from fridge to table, and my husband and I couldn't be more impressed with the taste! Rather than lightly brushing the salmon, I brushed both sides and then poured the remaining sauce into the bottom of the baking pan. The result was awesome - tender, flaky salmon that still tasted like salmon with a little ooomph added! I didn't think the sauce was overpowering at all, and was happy to find a recipe that was different than the plain ole' boring salmon I've grown used to.

text:
It was good... It definitely has the potential to be very, very excellent. However, I found it was a little too bland and the fish/salmon taste overpowered the dijon. I added a little pepper to the sauce, and used dried parsley, half bread crumbs half crumbled Breton crackers, and a little garlic powder in the crumbs, so maybe I messed it up! I also omitted the pecans so that might be the issue. I think next time I will try marinating the fish with the sauce in the refrigerator for 10 minutes on each side. On the other hand, my boyfriend really enjoyed it as is but he is a bigger salmon lover than me. =)

text:
Num!!!  This is so quick and easy!  I was home alone, so I did less butter but kept the mustard and honey the same for a nice thick sauce.  I dunked the salmon in and then thought, what the heck and just poured the entire mixture into a baking dish.  I then sprinkled on the breadcrumb mixture (which I added some salt and pepper to) and tossed in some asparagus right in with it all.  Baked for 15 minutes and wa-la!  A quick and easy meal for a single gal at home!  So tasty!  I'll cannot wait to impress some guests with this meal!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a DELICIOUS recipe!  The pecans are a hit on the salmon, and the yummy honey-mustard flavor is awesome.  My husband thinks it's good, but I think it's spectacular! :)  My only change is to turn and coat the salmon in the honey mustard mix, then dip and coat it in the bread mixture.  It's a little messy, but this will ensure a good flavoring of the salmon instead of just sprinkling crumbs on top and it either be too dry or plain.  I would also recommend NOT using thick salmon steaks ... you can taste the flavors blending better with a thinner fish.  Thanks!

text:
Good recipe, very helpful. I didn't make it exactly the same, I omitted the breadcrumbs and pecans.   I based what I did off several recipes from this site, and this one is the closest to what I did.   I made foil packets for the salmon... for the marinade I used a little white wine, freshly squeezed lemon juice, honey dijon mustard, honey sauce from KFC (lol, it's all I had!) and fresh ground mccormick lemon pepper seasoning. I added a slice of lemon on top and baked the foil packets. It came out very moist, flakey, and flavorful. It didn't taste fishy or "mustardy" at all, I don't like the fishy taste and this was good.

text:
I thought this was pretty good-the honey-mustard sauce was nice and moist and the bread crumbs added their own flavor. I used regular mustard because I didn't have Dijon, and I left out the pecans because I didn't have any-I'm sure they would have added to the flavor, but it was good without. The only weird thing was that instead of cooking through in 20 or so minutes, the fish was still kind of mushy and the bread crumbs on top weren't crispy. But it could be my oven :P

Update: 2nd attempt was better (I think)-I used Dijon mustard and my husband found an old bag of pecans and I think they really added to the flavor. This time we cooked for 12 minutes and the salmon was almost overdone :P And there were still extra crumbs on top. Tasty, though!

text:
I am amazed that this simple recipe made the most delicious salmon I have ever had. It tasted better than some restaurant salmon I've sampled. I followed the recipe to the letter except I had no pecans and no parsley. I also used panko. My fillets were very thick so I had to cook for a little longer..about 18-20 minutes total. The Dijon sauce was so good I felt like I could just drink it. It gave the fish this delicate sweetish,tangy-ish flavour but did not overpower that great salmon taste. Definitely my go-to fish recipe from now on.

text:
I thought there was nothing new that could be done to salmon that I hadn't eaten, but this was truly scrumptious!    The salmon came out perfectly cooked, not cloyingly sweet like honey-mustard things tend to and not overly mustardy, either. Perfect balance of flavors!  I made this yesterday for family visiting from out of town as an impromptu lunch during Passover.  Obviously, I made at least one substitution - I traded out the bread crumbs for matzoh that I processed along with the pecans.  I did toast the pecans a little bit, also.  The other oh-so-slight modification I made was to add about a tablespoon of chopped garlic to the matzoh/pecan/parsley mix.   I got raves from my guests who were oh-so-impressed with my extraordinary cooking abilities! lol Of course, I told them that it wasn't that I'm a good cook, it's that I found an awesome recipe!

My brother made this for me at Christmas and it was the best fish I'd ever had....but when I made it there wasn't the same exploding flavour and the topping wasn't as moist and the crumbliness made me want to scrape it off. As another reviewer said, there's loads of sauce which burnt in the bottom of my pan when I dumped it on. I used some extra on rice and it was great.

I'd make this again, but my review for my version is 3 stars and 5 for my brother's, so a 4 all around.

userID:
1358161
Display Name:
LISALOU3
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is just what I was looking for.  It is delicious.  I did change it a little just because I didn't have the exact ingredients.  I used 1 1/2 TBLS dijon mustard, 2 TBLS mesquite smoked BBQ sauce, 1 tsp. brown sugar and a TBSP melted margarine.  I marinated my salmon filets in this mixture for about 2 hours.  I mixed fine plain bread crumbs with pecan meal (pecans ground to a very fine consistency), salt and pepper and dredged the non-skin side of the filet in the crumb mixture and baked uncovered at 400 for about 15 minutes.  My filets were thin.  The topping is crunchy and so tasty.  The salmon is still really moist inside, but not mushy.  I will definitely make this again and try it with the honey, when I have some in the pantry. I'll be sharing this recipe with others.  Some have mentioned that it was very fishy, but if your salmon is fresh, it's not fishy tasting or fishy smelling.
Review:
Rating:
5

This was a complete success!  My husband said to put this on the "keeper" list and my daughter thoroughly enjoyed it, too.

This recipe was absolutely fabulous!  I'm not a fish lover, but I saw this recipe and decided to make it for my family and they loved it to.  Besides being very easy to make, it was very tasty and pretty much melted in your mouth.  I did not add the pecans as I don't really like them.  I also lined the baking pan with butter to create a gravy for the salmon.  When it was finished baking, I took the drippings and added another half a lemon to it to give it a tangy taste and it turned out great as well!  I loved this recipe, I would definitely make it again.

I used this on some frozen salmon filets. It was great. Another tip: the dijon I used already had sugar in it so it came out too sweet. Next time I will add less honey or use a different mustard.

A great alternative to marinating and grilling salmon, as I usually do. My family much preferred this "less fishy taste". Instead of just topping with the butter/honey mustard mixture, I instead covered/dunked the entire fillet with it (as you'd do with an egg batter) and breaded the whole thing before baking. I ommitted the pecans, because I didn't have any onhand, but I bet that would make it even better. Thanks!

I like the honey mustard mixture and added some parmesan cheese to the breadcrumbs.  I did use frozen fillets rather than fresh so that maybe where the problem lies.  I'm passing this recipe on to my mother who enjoys salmon too.  Thanks for sharing.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely fabulous!!  Salmon is one dish I order OFTEN when we eat out, and am delighted to finally find a recipe that resembles the salmon served in the finest restuarants...not like the poach in wine/broiled with lemon and butter varieties that are done ad nauseum.  Like another reviewer, I allowed the butter mix to cool and coagulate so that I could sop it alllll on.  I only deviated from the recipe with cook time.  Although I don't like overcooked salmon, I don't quite trust undercooked salmon, so I baked it for more like 20 min.  The sauce and breading would have been enough for an extra serving, by the way.  I won't be ordering salmon so often anymore.  Why should I?  This recipe tops them!  Many thanks, Arnie, for sharing this great recipe. In my top 10 for certain.

text:
This is the best salmon recipe that I have ever tried. It was fast and easy and the entire family loved it. I would probably cut back on the butter next time just to cut the fat. UPDATE 2006: I first rated this in 2002 and I thought I should update my review. I always cook my salmon this way. The only thing that I have changed is that I leave off the pecans and butter. I mix equal parts of the mustard and honey and spread it on the fish. My 8yr.old loves it so much that he will take the leftovers to school and eat them cold! Thanks again for this great recipie.

Had neither pecans nor parsley and instead added these as per suggestion :
In Breadcrumb mix: 2tsp garlic powder, 1tsp paprika, 1 or 2 tsp each of dried oregano and basil.

This was pretty good , but the toppings can be reduced by at least half-- and the butter should be reduced even more so that the honey and mustard flavors are predominant. Next time I may reduce the ratio of breadcrumbs to pecans also. Otherwise it was a quick and yummy main dish worth serving to company. 
Note: Tried this a second time with changes noted above; I also let the butter-mustard-honey mixture cool a bit so that it thickened, before brushing it on the fish. It stayed on better and held the nut topping better. Upgrading to five stars with these changes. Delicious!

userID:
17029463
Display Name:
Megan Newton
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dish for the first time last night, and it turned out wonderful. My husband (the BBQ King) had planned on barbecuing the 2 pound salmon fillet we had in the fridge, but instead I cut it in half and used this recipe - only making minor adjustments... He took one bite and said every time we have salmon it needs to be made like this! I used 1/2 cup butter and closer to 3 tbsp honey when making the sauce. I had also bought the cheapest Dijon mustard I could find. I let the butter sauce thicken slightly before heavily slathering both sides of the fish (my filet had no skin) and I let it marinade in the fridge for about an hour and a half. When it was time to get the oven ready I took it out of the fridge and moved both pieces of the salmon fillet from the square pan I had it in to marinade, to a roasting pan covered in foil... At the same time putting the butter sauce in the microwave for 30 seconds. Once it was melted I slathered both sides of the fish one more time before adding the bread topping (I used Panko breading and added 1/4 cup parmesan cheese). I put it in the oven for 20 minutes, then put it in the broiler on medium heat for two minutes. I did not add any salt, pepper, lemon, or anything else suggested and it came out perfectly! I have never had fish cooked so wonderfully, and there was absolutely nothing soggy about the coating. The broiler added the perfect touch to the crispiness in the breading. I will definitely be making this again!

text:
This is an exceptionally good recipe.   Great taste, easy and quick to make...

 Salmon is one of our favorite meals. I made this recipe for the first time... As I always do when making a recipe for the first time ...I follow the recipe as closely as possible... I used panko  for my bread crumbs, and maille  dijon mustard.

When I make this recipe again, I will go with a thicker coating of the mustard honey sauce on the Salmon and increase the pecan content...  I might add a little salt before serving

I served the Salmon with rice  and asparagus with hollandaise sauce.  I used fresh sockeye filets.

Writing this review makes me want to make this gem of a recipe soon.

text:
I never found a recipe that I liked for salmon, until this one! This is absolutely delicious, and has been a huge hit at every holiday I've made it for (which has now been several)! Although it's great the way the recipe states, over time I've made a few small changes. I first salt and pepper the filet itself, and sprinkle some lemon juice over it. I also don't use the pecans, and instead use panko breadcrumbs in place of regular. I add lemon juice and fresh garlic to the mustard and honey mixture, along with the fresh parsley. SO good!!!

Dijon and salmon didn't sound like a good combination to me, but it actually works!  Good flavor - the dijon is not overwhelming.  I would brush each salmon filet generously and cut the sauce in half (you'll just throw the excess away anyhow).  Leave the pecans a bit chunky for texture.  I was worried it would be too dry with no marinade in the pan, but it was perfect.

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2014-02-13T17:09:28.387
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4271606
Display Name:
Chia the Cooking Maven
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
29
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1101525.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think the basic recipe would be great, but I had to change ingredients according to what I had on hand. It turned out amazingly good!
 
I placed two hefty Salmon Steaks (1.72 lbs. total) on a cookie sheet lined with non-stick aluminum foil sprayed with Wegmans 100% Extra Virgin Olive Oil Spray.

I added about 3/4 Tbsp. of Horseradish Mustard to the Dijon Mustard (last of the jar) and used Ian's All Natural Whole Wheat Panko Bread Crumbs & 1 Tbsp. dried parsley. Due to dairy sensitivity, I replaced the butter with *Earth Balance Soy Free Natural Buttery Spread (Butter would be to die for!), and used Wegmans Organic Wildflower Honey.

I slathered the Mustard/*Butter/Honey mixture on the salmon. Coated them heavily with the Panko/Pecan/Parsley mixture. Flipped the fish over and repeated on the other side. I also took a toothpick and secured the thinner "tails" of each fish together to prevent them from over-cooking.

Baked the fish, turning halfway through cooking, until done. (145 degrees internal temperature.) They were perfectly done.

Served with two side dishes:
 
1. Jasmin Rice & Baby Bella Mushrooms. Rice cooked in water seasoned with Organic Better than Bouillon Chicken Base (about a rounded Tbsp). Mushrooms sauteed in small amount of Pure Sesame Oil and Asian Stir-fry oil.

2. Steamed fresh Asparagus.

My adult son, with a fine pallet, said this must be made again.

Yummy!  I have usually made salmon with just dijon and honey, but the butter sauce and crunchy topping were delicious.  I substituted 1 tsp. dried parsley as another reviewer suggested because that's all I had on hand.  Also used walnuts in place of pecans because that's what I had.  I think it will be even better with pecans. Served with couscous and corn-on-the-cob.  Super fast and yummy!

city:

country:
None
text:
After getting a ton of salmon fillets on sale at my local grocer I had to start hunting for more recipes than the average kinds. I was afraid of this dish at first for fear it might be to sweet/tangy but man I was wrong. Even my toddler loved it (with some of the toppings taken off as to not be to strong for his little taste buds). 

The only things I did a wee bit different was used only 3/4 of the Dijon and put the pecans through an electric chopper to make them crumb size. And I didn't brush lightly with the sauce. I put a good amount on. 

Everyone's tastes are different so take the negative comments with a grain of salt. If you like a nice sweet touch to your fish (think maple salmon) this recipe will do. If your into just the regular herbed/wine fish then this might be to much on the taste level for you.

text:
We thought this came out great!  Much better than the Maple one that has tons of ratings.  My only caveat would be that if you have fresh thick salmon steaks, count on much longer cooking time.   And by fresh, I mean, caught by my husband.  The thickness was around 1 inch in the middle and at minimum took 25 minutes.  So pay close attention to the "until flakes easily with fork" rather than the time of 12-15 minutes.

country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe: anyone who calls is bland/tasteless is either used to overseasoned or overspiced food. This had a nice tang with a fair amount of sweet (I did not use salt or pepper).

The only issue with this recipe is, when used with 4 (4 ounce) fillets, the sauce and crumbs are way too much. I would cut the mustard mix down by about 1/4 and the breadcrumb mix down by 1/2 (keep the proportions the same, the volume just needs to drop).

Other than that, this dish was awesome and easy to make. Everyone loved it. (Served with steamed broccoli and sugar snap peas.)

text:
This salmon was absolutely delicious! I made it for dinner today, just finished eating so I came back on here to rave about it! After reading several of the reviews, I decided to keep the recipe almost exactly the same. The only tiny change I made was to use panko crumbs instead of breadcrumbs because I wanted more crunch. But that's it! I used whole grain dijon mustard and the frozen salmon fillets that you can buy in a vacuum packed package (I left them in the fridge overnight to defrost, per the package instructions). The fillets fit perfectly into my 9x13 glass baking dish and they were cooked perfectly after 15 minutes. I served the salmon with basmati rice (boiled with a chicken bouillon cube) and marinated spinach with chickpeas and onions. The entire meal was to die for and I couldn't believe how good it tasted! I will definitely be using this recipe again for salmon.. it was so easy and tasty! Check out the photo I posted as well :)

userID:
1852143
Display Name:
OConnorCook
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Divine! Hands down the best salmon recipe I have ever used, and I make salmon 2-3 times per week. I made a few modifications, but not because I wanted to tinker with the recipe; I read the recipe wrongly (thought it was equal parts honey to dijon mustard), was low on butter, and ran out of honey! 
What I did:
I used 1 T butter, 1 T honey, 2-3 T dijon mustard, 1 T lite maple syrup. I used cornbread crumbs instead of breadcrumbs because it was what I had on hand. I applied the mustard mix liberally to both sides, sprinkled both sides with the cornbread topping, and reserved the rest of the mustard mix, adding about 1 t. white vinegar per the advice of other reviewers and then used the remainder as a dipping sauce. OUTSTANDING! 

My fillets were around 5-7 oz. I baked at 400 for 13 minutes and they were a bit overdone for my taste. Next time I will reduce baking time by a couple minutes. The finished product was still superb and we gobbled it up, but I like my salmon a little less done. 

I never, ever review recipes, but this is truly a phenomenal one and warrants a review. I cannot praise it enough! My husband and I both talked about it all evening. I am already looking forward to making it again. Delicious, easy, fast, and versatile. The best salmon recipe bar none!

text:
I am a creature of habit and make the same things all the time.  However, for some reason, this reciped inspired me, and I'm not even a big fan of salmon.  I prepared this last night for my husband, who loves salmon, my parents, both of whom are incredible chefs, my grandmother and my uncle.  All of them were impressed and sincerely loved it.  I even loved it.  I am already looking forward to making it again and impressing my friends. I still can't believe how easy it was to prepare.  I followed the instructions pretty closely.  As recommened by another reviewer, I recommend tasting the honey mustard before putting on the salmon.  I think the key is that they honey cuts the strong mustard taste.  Also, I definitely recommend serving with a lemon wedge.  The fresh lemon juice added some extra magic to it all.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this gluten free and lower carb by simply deleting the bread crumbs, adding a few more nuts and replacing the honey with splenda or some other lower carb sweetener. Even those who are not diabetic or on a gluten free diet enjoy it. I salt and pepper, top with mustard mixture, then nuts and either cilantro or parsley.....always a hit. I've done this with both fresh and frozen salmon. Of course fresh is best but frozen is handy. Just pop the frozen salmon out of the freezer and proceed as above, bake a little longer.

text:
My lower rating could be due to my error. I had a lot more marinade than I think was necessary and put it all on my fish fillets thinking more is better. It wasn't. It was too much sweet and I think caused the fish to be soggy. I couldn't get a crust on it. If I make again I will definitely only lightly brush the marinade on. And I will use less honey if any, due to the sweetness.

Delicious! I misread amount of mustard and honey and used 4 tablespoons of each instead of the stated, but turned out fabulous. Also didn't melt butter, just softened it and mixed together. Used Panko bread crumbs instead of plain ones. Had some fresh chives in garden, so added some with the parsley. Served with steamed asparagus, drizzled with the honey and mustard sauce (had extra since I used more honey and mustard). Husband loved it! Will make again.

text:
I really liked this salmon recipe. I used Smart Balance instead of butter (healthier), and I used walnuts instead of pecans because I only had walnuts on hand. I let the sauce sink into the salmon a bit before adding the walnut topping. The end result was a subtly sweet and tangy salmon dish with a delightful crunch. I served this with honey roasted potatoes and lemon squash, and it was a great, relatively quick dinner.

text:
This is one of those dishes where I'm shocked that anyone wouldn't give it 5 stars. But then again, you can't please everyone. I follow it to a tee and everyone loves it. In my estimation there are people who love salmon and don't want anything to overpower the flavor and those who tolerate salmon and couldn't care less either way. I suppose the former may not like this recipe because the mustard can add a lot of flavor (we use german mustard). We eat salmon at least twice a month and this a delicious and simple way to change things up. Hooray for another excellent addition to Lenten Friday dinners!!

text:
First off, I am not a fish lover.  I make salmon once in a while and that is it.  With that being said, this is one of the best salmon recipes I've ever made!  I used a lot of the sauce & was very generous when I brushed the salmon with it.  It turned out great!  I also didn't have pecans - used crushed sunflower seeds instead which were great too.  One extra thing I did was to place a little slice of butter on top of the crumb mixture before baking and I thought it turned out great that way - I seasoned the salmon w/salt and pepper before brushing the sauce on.  Squeezed lemon over the top before serving is a nice little addtion.  I served white rice & grilled summer squash sprinkled w/garlic salt - delicious!  It was a great meal.  I will definitely make this one again.  So glad I tried it!  I will be making salmon more often now! :)

text:
I love this recipe!  I have made it for myself as well as for guests and everyone just loves it!  The only things that I do a little differently are that I use dill instead of parsley and I do my own breadcrumbs so they are a bit coarser than the ones that you buy in the store.  Personally, I think that salmon demands dill, they go so well together.  I will be making this recipe again and again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a nice alternative to my usual methods of preparing salmon. The only changes I made were to use Italian -style bread crumbs (eliminating the need for parsley) and to halve everything for two servings. I found that my filets took a bit longer to cook, more like 20 minutes. After tasting the honey-mustard sauce prior to cooking, I actually expected to enjoy this more, but it seemed like the flavor mellowed while baking. The topping was quite tasty, though, and my husband seemed to really like the dish. He said this was his second favorite salmon recipe, behind the maple salmon from this site. All in all, I will make this again, but I may increase the amount of sauce next time.

text:
Ok, so I did change it a tad, but still, this was very very good.  And maybe I was just extra hungry, but I have tried alot of fish recipes and was just never quite happy.  This one just hit the spot.  I did use tilapia in an effort to shop thriftier, and I also only had almonds on hand.  I used a lite margarine instead of butter.  There was an abundance of crumb mixture so I put it in the freezer to save for another day.  I used Italian crumbs so I didnt add any other spices, not even S&P.  I did hit it with the broiler just to brown it up a bit.  Served with a salad w/lite dressing and lite cottage cheese, and I didnt feel like I was deprived of anything.  Will make this again for sure.  Thank you for sharing
----- just to update, I made it w/Salmon and pecans, exactly as written and it is delish!

city:

country:
None
text:
Very easy recipe, most ingredients already in your pantry.  I didn't have parsley or nuts, so I just used more breadcrumbs (some of which were panko breadcrumbs so it would stay crunchy) and some lemon/herb seasoning mixed into the breadcrumbs.  I added 2 tsp of lemon juice into the butter mixture.  I coated both sides of the fish (after de-skinning), and put down parchment paper on the pan so the bottom wouldn't stick or burn.  This was AWESOME and CHEAP, and my husband ate 2 pieces (and he usually hates fish).  It was so good I am serving it at the next dinner party! Literally no cleanup due to the parchment paper, and no fishy smell in the kitchen.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, did I get excellent reviews when I made this one!  I will possibly switch from grilling to baking altogether now!  It was so delectable and tender, and the glaze tamed the strong flavor of the salmon.  When I ate it, I was thinking it needed more of a sweetness to it, so the next night, for different people, I made it with double the honey!   So good!   This still gets a five, though, because I could imagine serving this many times to come!  Here are my tips:   Tip #1:  Double the honey. Tip #2:  Don't brush the fillets.  Put the glaze in a shallow bowl and dip each fillet in it quickly before placing it on your cooking pan. Tip #3:  Use a Silpat (a silicone pad that is made for cooking pans so bottoms of foods don't get overcooked or burnt onto your nice cookware)--the clean up is so much easier. Tip #4:  If you don't have a food processor, the crust might be frustrating to create.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As always, choosing fresh, wild (NOT farmed) salmon is crucial to a good outcome. I tend to be a salmon purist and I like to keep flavorings light and simple so as not to take away from the salmon flavor (usually I grill on an alder plank). However, my grill is broken and I decided to try something different with a coho salmon that I had just caught. I was pleasantly surprised that the dijon flavor and nuts compimented the salmon so well. If I make it again I will use 1/2 the called-for dijon and try using a little rosemary and spread the sauce just a little thinner (it is still easy to drown out the delicate salmon flavor). My kids loved it.

text:
This was very easy to prepare and the sauce had a good flavor, however it tended crumble off the fish as I tried to eat it.  Also, the salmon didn't really absorb the flavor.  I will make this again, only next time I will marinate the salmon in the mixture without the breadcrumbs for several hours before cooking, and then I will brush the breadcrumbs on last, right before I pop it in the oven.  I think it will absorb more flavor that way.

text:
This is a recipe that is versatile enough to have on a week night after work or for company. It is one of the first recipes I made from allrecipes.com and I continue to return to it time and again. I generally use salmon steaks and make fresh bread crumbs (any extra I keep on hand in the freezer). Sometimes I use the parsley, but just as often I don't. In 2001, I was a celebrity cook at a local restaurant, and this is the recipe I made - it was a hit with the customers, and I had a blast making it. Thanks Arnie for your recipe - it's  such a family favourite  that when my son comes home for a visit, more often than not this is one recipe he asks for.

text:
I really enjoyed this!  I wasn't sure I would, because I've tried another dijon salmon from this site and didn't like it very much.  This one is very, very good though.  I love the honey and pecans.  At first it almost seemed too sweet but mellowed out as I ate.  I cut down on the butter by one TBS. but then added a splash of olive oil because I feared the mustard would be too strong.  I also used fresh basil instead of parsley.  This was done very fast!  Was done under 15 minutes in the oven.  Served with steamed broccoli and a whole-wheat baguette.

I will have to say this recipe deserved a triple WOW!!!  My niece, who doesn't like ANYTHING actually liked this dish.  My daughter and I truly enjoyed this recipe and I can guarantee that we will be making it again.  I did substitute the dijon mustard for honey dijon. My daughter and I were both leery on what this would taste like because neither one of us are mustard fans.  But this meal was AWESOME and something she and I will both consider a family favorite!

What a great dish!  I live in AK so I'm always looking for easy and tasty salmon dishes.  Salt and peppered the filets, put a thick layer of the sauce on the top and bottom and put on extra pecan topping (omitted the breadcrumbs like some suggested) and it turned out great! The topping was crunchy and the salmon was moist...baking fish in silicone bakeware, if you haven't tried it, also keeps you from "drying" out your fish dishes.

It was a big hit and easy to make, especially for someone who lacks any kind of kitchen sense (me).  Based on some of the suggestions: 1)I did not use the pecans, 2)I marinated the salmon in the sauce for 20 mins, 3) and I didn't add the bread crumb until the last 5 minutes before it was done baking.  I will definitely be making this again!

text:
I was going to prepare this a few weeks ago for a dinner party. After reading a few negative reviews I was afraid to test it on company. Last night I made it for my family. I made 2 changes. I seasoned the filets with Old Bay seasoning and I eliminated the nuts. We loved it. Simple, and tasty. The honey and mustard were not overpowering as I expected.
Next dinner party I will debut this one.

text:
Salmon came out soooo tender and juicy!  Flaked right off of the skin.  The dijon flavor was light and mildly sweet- an excellent complement to the salmon.  I skipped out on the pecans and made my own breadcrumbs seasoned with thyme, basil, and oregano.  Topped with a sprinkle of salt and pepper and garnished with fresh cilantro and lemon...a masterpiece!  Try drizzling a little of the extra dijon sauce on the plate for added effect.  5 stars!!!

I've eaten a lot of salmon in my life, my friends. A LOT. Prepared many different ways. This is, hands down, the best salmon I have EVER eaten and I refuse to prepare salmon any other way ever since I discovered this amazing recipe. It is SO GOOD. 

I don't lightly brush the mustard/honey/butter, though, I smear the whole bowl on the salmon and cover it in breadcrumbs and pecans when I have them. 

With or without pecans, it's still incredible. I'm using this recipe for the fifth time tonight and I can't wait. Yum yum!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I rated this a 5 even though I made a few changes.  I didn't use bread crumbs (gave bread up for lent), Didn't have pecans I used about 1 tsp . of Italian seasoning on a 1 lb.  fillet. placed skin side down. Then I drizzled Honey and Dejon mustard over top  (It also ran little bit down sides).  Put it on low broil for 10 min. Removed from oven,turned fillet over, removed skin,  and drizzled more honey and mustard on, then back under low broiler for 7 min.  This was the best salmon I ever had.   I will make this again and again. After lent I will use bread crumbs and pecans.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't eat fish, so this rating is really my husband's.  I did cook it though, something I don't often prepare, so I thought I'd share a few thoughts.  The only thing I did differently was the size of the salmon fillet.  I purchased  a half-pound (8oz) filet, which was a good portion size for one serving.  If I'd cut it in half (2  servings) the cooking time given would probably have been perfect.  I cooked it 12 minutes and it was cooked on the ends but not the thicker middle.  I put it back in for an additional 4 minutes and it was perfect.
For the sauce - I cut all measurements in half which game me more than enough for the fillet.  For myself, a person with a strong aversion to cooking fish, this was actually a pleasure to prepare.  Simple, no heavy fish smell, and my husband loved it.  So a heartfelt  "Thank you" to Esmee.  I will be making this again and again!

text:
Ok, so ladies don't tar and feather me for this, but I made this in a rush one morning before my morning coffee. Never make anything before your coffee.  I put everything in a bowl and mixed it up except for the salmon.  When I realized what I did it was too late.  I just put a little bit of the now spread down on the glass pie plate I was going to cook them in.  I then set the salmon on top of it, and added the rest around the salmon like a salmon coffin patting it down on the top and sides.   I covered it with plastic to cook later and refrigerated.  My husband said it was the best salmon I had prepared to date.  Next time I will try to get it right, but prepared the way I did it by accident it was amazing!

I found this recipe today for my wild salmon fillet and it was absolutely scrumptious!  The dijon with honey & butter was wonderful to keep the salmon from drying out while it baked and I used panko bread crumbs, chopped pecans and tarragon, fine sea salt and fresh ground pepper.  It is the best recipe to keep the salmon moist and it was so tender!  My hubby loved it!  I served it with baked zucchini fries (with panko, parmesan, salt and pepper and olive oil and served all with jasmine rice.  Awesome salmon dinner!!!

text:
I had rockfish, so used combo Mayo, honey and Dijon along with tarragon and topped with pecans and pinko crumbs.  I put tbsp olive oil on pan laid fish in and slathered mixture on.  I had to pour off watery liquid and put back in Toaster oven on lowest rack, and put the broiler on for few minutes to crisp up. My hubby LOVED it

text:
The first time I made this I followed the recipe to the T. and found the different flavors went very well together. This last time I made it I made a few slight changes to mellow the sweet of the honey out just a touch. I added a teaspoon of minced garlic to the mustard mixture and crumbled a toasted hamburger bun by hand rather than use traditional white or wheat bread crumbs. The slight flavor changes turned out better than expected.

The original recipe is excellent all on its own and well worth 5 stars.

text:
I can't imagine people not liking this recipe or saying it is bland.  IT IS DELICIOUS!  I did add some chopped fresh garlic but not necessary.  I also doubled the sauce to have some for dipping as another reviewer suggested.  I did run out of dijon doing that and used some Inglehoffer stone ground mustard and that worked great.  My husband is NOT a fan of salmon but I am trying to get him to eat it for health benefits and he said it is for sure a keeper.  My 16 year-old who normally is just okay with any kind of fish devoured it and loved the sauce.  Thank you for an excellent recipe.  For sure going in the "rotation!"

text:
Great flavor and texture!  I add 2 finely minced garlic cloves to the honey mustard mixture.  I also added 2 teaspoons of garlic grapeseed oil to the bread crumb mixture so that it would hold and brown better...olive oil would be fine as well.  Served it over a kale-spinach mixture and used the drippings to wilt the greens.  Squeeze the lemons over it as a finishing taste. Delicious!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made some minor changes. I didn't have dijon mustard but I had balsamic mustard and that was delicious. I used Kirkland's frozen fillets (Costco) which are 7 oz each so I followed the directions exactly for the two of us, using two fillets. I didn't have fresh parsley but Penzey's dried parsley is excellent. And I used panko bread crumbs, giving the coating a nice crunch. Hubby practically licked his plate. I served with plain green beans and plain red potato, avoiding my usual inclination to add stuff to the side dishes, since I realized there would be so much flavor in the fish. Good move! This will become a staple for us and for guests!

I have now made this several times, following the recipe exactly and making subtle changes. For my husband's diet, I deleted the honey and the butter and used less crumbs. Still absolutely delicious. Every time I've made this, it has been delicious. In short, it's the recipe that keeps on working. I wish I could give it ten stars! ETA: I highly recommend, on all recipes, using a probe to make sure the food is done the way you like it. Stick it in the piece you are most likely to eat, and no one will notice the hole it makes, and you are guaranteed to have it done perfectly every time!

text:
Had planned to grill out salmon but thunderstorm nixed that.   In a panic to find a simple recipe that I could fix in time for expected company, I tried this recipe.  Everyone loved it!  One guest said it was the best salmon he had ever eaten and two days later had his wife call me for the recipe.   My husband, who will eat salmon but is not crazy about it, said that he would love for me to fix it again soon.   I didn't have any parsley in the house, so had to omit it, but the dish was still delicious.  I had to use lightly salted cashews because I didn't have any pecans, and they gave it a delicious crunch.   I fixed it again the following week with the parsley and pecans and it was even better.  Definitely a keeper!

text:
Wow!  This was the best ever!  I doubled the recipe and used it to top four salmon filets and also three mahi mahi filets (to make sure we had enough for our guests).  It came out looking good, and even the kids said that it tasted good.  As a note, I used finely crushed Ritz crackers for the breadcrumbs (just what was available) which worked well.  We had this with the Baked Asparagus with Balsamic Butter Sauce, which bakes at the same temperature, just a few minutes less.  It's an excellent pairing, and makes the flow of dinner really easy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dish for a party of 15 and it was delicious but I sub and added a few ingredients to it along with all the other ingredients. Instead of using bread crumbs, I used matzo meal with teaspoon of smoke paprika and a teaspoon fresh mince oregano with the parleys. I also added fresh mince garlic into the spread and that really brings out the flavors. I did marinade my salmon with light sea salt first then prepared the salmon ahead of time about 5 hours in advanced. That marinade stage made a big difference in flavor and moisture. Every one raves about how moist the salmon and toasted crunch of the salmon. Delicious and yes will make it again.

text:
Lets just say I'm in love with this recipe....understatement. I usually steam my salmon in a foil packet but this time I decided to put it straight into the oven with this dijon sauce and bread crumb topping...it took this salmon to the next level!! It definitely balances out the fishy taste of salmon. Came out super moist and flavorful! If you're a fan of spicy I would say throw some cayenne pepper in the honey dijon mixture, but it is just as good on its own. Will be using this recipe from now on!

Yummy.  This was an interesting way to prepare baked salmon and it was good!  I know some may say it was bland BUT, luckily,  I seasoned my bread crumbs with garlic powder, black pepper & Season All seasoning so it can bake  'in' the salmon, which was flavorful!   

I didn't use pecans (I dont like pecans) or any nuts. I used dried parsley instead of fresh parsley.  Lastly,  I added cayenne pepper on top of the breadcrumbs before entering the oven. It was yummy!

 Next time, I may try it with the skin off the bottom for lil more flavor. ...

I have been making this recipe for years now, and absolutely love it! It has always been highly praised by family and friends,  and is my "go to" recipe for first time guests, when fresh salmon is in season etc.  Delicious and easy, nice presentation too.
I am so surprised to see any negative reviews? I don't just brush the top of the salmon however, I dunk it into the honey dijon mustard mix and generously coat it with the sauce and panko crumb mixture, also add additional minced garlic.

Despite the overall rave reviews I almost didn't try this recipe due to reading some of the less than stellar reviews given. My husband was the one who convinced me stating "some people are always not going to like something's". So I went ahead and gave it a try, and I'm sure glad I did. This tasted great! And it passed the husband test, as he throughly enjoyed it too. I followed the recipe exactly except I replaced finely chopped pecans with finely chopped walnuts (that's all I had in the pantry). I used the extra honey Dijon mixture as a dip for the salmon and my sweet potatoes. Overall, great dish. I'm not sure why there are even bad reviews for this recipe to begin with!

text:
This was very simple to make. The result is a super moist and very tasty salmon! We loved this and will definitely make it again. I didn't have the parsley so I put in a sprinkle of dried Italian seasoning. I used Italian bread crumbs because that's all I ever buy and I added in a sprinkle of garlic and wine seasoning. I'm not sure about the lady who said it was bland because this had such a wonderful flavor. With the mixture that you brush on the salmon, I'm not sure how it could come out bland at all. Very much worth trying this recipe out!

I have been using this exact recipe for a number of years. It is my go-to recipe for guests and raves always follow. The only change I make is to use Panko bread crumbs for the extra crunch. A little tip: triple or quadruple the recipe for each of the two components and keep them in the fridge for that quick dinner after coming home. They will keep nicely for at least a week.

text:
I made this meal for meal prep and it was awesome even days later! Just a few small changes I made, I used a honey-flavored Dijon mustard and cut back a little on the honey. I then coated both sides of the salmon sprinkling salt and pepper on both sides before adding the bread crumb mixture, this way I know it is well seasoned instead of just tasting salty on top. I unfortunately had to cook it on 425 since I had other things in the oven but it still came out perfect despite forgetting about it for a minute or two.  But it was VERY tasty! I made an Asparagus-Bacon dish as the side and it was quite popular in the teacher's lounge the next day! :)

text:
Strange combination of flavors. I followed the recipe precisely and, although the fish looked terrific, the flavors did not come together at all. You taste the subtle salmon and then get blasts of honey-mustard, which is very overpowering. My whole family agreed that the flavors just don't go well together. The breadcrumb-nut topping adds some great texture, but we'll try it with a different sauce next time.

text:
I liked the recipe.  Made it according to the directions.  I seasoned the salmon with salt and pepper first, then added a thick layer of the butter sauce followed by the breadcrumb mixture.  The topping, while tasty, was pretty dry.  It was tasty enough to try again, but next time I will probably try mixing the breadcrumb mixture with the honey-mustard-butter mix and then spread it on top.  My salmon was about 1 1/2 inches thick at it's thickest.  I used a convection oven for 15 minutes on 400 and it came out perfectly cooked.

I think this is a wonderful recipe for salmon. Thank you. The only alteration I made was to reduce the mustard to two tablespoons. It's our personal preference since we find the Dijon mustard quite powerful. I served it on a bed of arugula. After reading other reviews who said this was bland, I think it might have something to do with how fresh your salmon is. It was not at all bland. We loved it and it's a keeper!

userID:
12964776
Display Name:
sg
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
29
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe today and I was very pleased with it. A lot of ppl said this recipe was bland so I added a few more condiments like adobo and paprika to the bread crumbs(which were Italian) and also Parmesan cheese. I didn't use pecans because I didn't have any but I added some pressed garlic as another reviewer suggested. I also only used 1tbs of honey because I didn't want it to be to sweet. I had enough sauce to generously coat the fish but not have left overs. After it was cooked I squeezed a lemon over it. I paired the fish with a seasoned baked yam and creme of spinach. The mixture of flavors was amazing! Don't over do the mustard as the taste is very rich.
Review:

Thank you for the wonderful dinner!

text:
Fantastic! When the weather gets cold, I don't like going outside to grill, and I was looking for a different way to prepare salmon. This recipe was not only easy to make, but very tasty. I added just a touch more Dijon mustard because I like Dijon mustard, otherwise, I followed the recipe directions to the letter, except instead of brushing each salmon filet "lightly", I brushed each filet "generously".  I served the salmon with a mixed green salad and it was a hit. My wife loved it. I don't understand people who "hate" this recipe, they must be difficult to please. Perhaps they can hire a personal chef to make their salmon to please their palate. Sheesh.

text:
I did not care for this at all. My hubs thought this was "OK," but didn't like the pecans at all. I agree and think it was the pecans that turned me off most (they are totally out of place IMHO). The glaze is also a tad too mustard-y for my liking. I pretty much followed Esmee's directions to the letter but had to improvise because I misread part of them. I forgot to add my melted butter to my honey mustard mixture, so I added it to my breadcrumb / pecan mixture instead. I think this really helped the topping crisp up nicely (the highlight of this meal). All in all, I'm glad to have given this a try, but this is just not for me (sorry!). Thanks anyways, Esmee.

text:
Easy, delicious & quick recipe that the hubby & kids liked a lot. Subbed 2 tsp dried parsley for 4 tsp fresh parsley. Used on 1.5 # salmon, as there was a lot of sauce & we need more than a pound for dinner. Even using extra salmon, I still had a little sauce left after coating the fillets with bread crumb/pecan mixture...drizzled this over the top of the fillets & cooked 15 minutes. Very tasty & no leftovers, so I consider this a success!  Thanks for the great recipe Esmee!

text:
Made this for dinner tonight. I easily pared it down for just 1 serving. My daughter doesn't do ANY kind of fish, and my son was at work. I think next time I will use less butter as it made a lot of sauce, but I still want the tanginess of the mustard and the sweetness of the honey to come out. Also I crushed a couple of almonds since I didn't have pecans. Using the Panko breadcrumbs gave it a nice crunch finish. I will definitely make this again. I like the suggestions of adding some cayenne pepper too, so I may try that next time as well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'd give this 4.5 stars if I could.  It was different and very tasty.  Very nice change of pace from the normal soy sauce themed recipes.  I used light butter (about 3 tablespoons since I had 2 pieces of salmon), the full amount of mustard and honey and used 3 tablespoons each of pecans and Panko crumbs. Since I used soft light butter, I just mixed the mustard and honey into the butter (without melting).  This made for a thicker paste that was easy to spread on top of the fish.  I had a bit of the topping mix left over, so I"ll cut that down to a 2 serving size when we have it again.

None
text:
I make this about once a week, this is one of our favorite dishes!  As some others have noted the butter-mustard-honey mixture is a LOT of sauce, I recommend dividing it before putting half on the raw fish and reserving the other half as a dipping sauce for the table.  It's best written, but if I'm feeling lazy I won't make the breadcrumbs mixture and just sprinkle some on directly from the can.  The sauce adds enough flavor for it to still be excellent, but add the parsley and nuts if you have them.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an amazing recipe- the flavors are delicious with the salmon. If you are health conscious you can omit the butter and add 2 TBSP of olive oil instead. I also did not use breadcrumbs as I did not have any on hand and I found the pecans gave it enough flavor and texture that I will not be using breadcrumbs at all on this dish in the future. Thanks for the dish Esmee

Not bad, however, it's too buttery and fatty for my taste. Because salmon is a naturally fatty fish, I think it tastes overly fatty if you add butter. In my opinion, salmon tastes better with a a lighter sauce - for instance, olive oil + soy sauce + lemon.

text:
This recipe was wonderful, first time I ever cooked fish. The fish took 15- 20 in my oven and even though the recipe doesn't say it, always skin the fish before baking unless otherwise instructed. Or you can also put down aluminum foil and the skin will stick to it. The recipe is great as is but I was cooking for gluten, red meat, and lactose intolerant guests, so I substituted olive oil and nixed the bread crumbs, still great.

Update: It doesn't even need the bread crumbs, I don't even use them anymore.

text:
Normally I don't like sweet food, especially on fish. However, this recipe  was perfect for salmon. I used Targets salmon (defrosted), Morehouse Classic Dijon mustard, Target brand honey, and unsalted butter.  In addition, I used Panko bread crubs seasoned with crushed pecans, creole seasoning and dried parsley flake.  Other than that I followed the insturctions.  My husband also liked that there was no fishy salmon taste.  Enjoy with Quinoa and veggies!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't follow the recipe exactly as I had only a few filets, but basically I took all the ingredients and eyeballed it. I used more honey than mustard after reading others' comments as I don't like things TOO mustardy and the sweet sounded goo with the fish. I sprayed the pyrex dish with cooking spray, set the fish down, put the mixture on first then sprinkled a generous about of crumbs and parsley on top and added the pecans and an extra drizzle of honey. I coated the top with more cooking spray because I find this helps everything stay moist.  I found it to be a really nice change from my normal sage or basil salmon.

text:
This was great. I made a few tweaks: I used boneless, SKINLESS salmon (from Sam's club - note: none of the "high-end" gorcery stores e.g. Whole Foods sell affordable skinless salmon). This wiped out the "yucky fish" faction of my family who all loved the final result. I also chopped two tablespoons of fresh tarragon from my garden and mixed it with the Dijon before spreading on the fish (this put it over the top). I also added a little garlic powder and fresh ground pepper to the bread crumbs to give them a little zip.

text:
This was certainly delicious, but as a recipe, I have to knock it a little bit. It's a bit bland. If you take a nice fresh salmon fillet and top it with bread crumbs, parsley, dijon, and plenty of butter, then it darn well better taste good! How could it not? I guess I'd have appreciated something with either a bit more flavor or a bit less fat. Still, though, if you want a very solid and guaranteed-to-please, traditional recipe, this will do the trick.

text:
I've been making this for about 5 years now, and we never tire of it. It's our favorite way to cook salmon. I follow the recipe as written except I use a whole fillet instead of individual 4 oz pieces. Last night I tried it substituting boneless, skinless chicken breasts for the salmon. It was very good, but we all agreed that we prefer the salmon. (I pounded the chicken breasts to about 1/3 in. and cooked them at 350 for 40 mins.)
Review:
