text:
I did thoroughly enjoy this salmon recipe, however the only problem I had is that it needed a lot more of the Dijon sauce! I'm just beginning to cook and this was simple, straightforward, and came out looking great! If you like the fishy taste of Salmon then follow the directions to a T. If not, then adding a few extra coats of the dressing will make all the difference in the world and will make a nice, but not overwhelming, compliment to the dish. Very, very nice.

text:
I LOVELOVELOVE salmon and wanted something quick for dinner, so I tried this recipe. DEE-LICIOUS!!! I didn't have dijon mustard, so I used sweet vidalia onion mustard, and it was excellent. The only thing is, next time I make it, I might half the amount of butter; I don't think it needed quite so much. And cut back just a tad on the bread crumbs. I baked it a little longer than 15 minutes because of the thickness of the fillet. I ate it with some fresh steamed asparagus, and it was YUMMY! Even my cat wanted some! Thanks!

text:
Mustard often over powers the flavor of Salmon but in this case it was perfect. We had no dijon so I used horseradish mustard....i bet the dijon tastes a little better. I have kids who don't eat pecans yet so I cooked them in the skillet with a bit of sugar and water and put them on the side. I cooked a half of salmon, using the serving of 4 suggested on the main page. I upped the bread by a bit, but it wasn't necessary. Thank you for the recipe!

text:
Great starter recipe but definitely needs some tweaking to make the taste pop.  I would definitely up the dijon to 5 tablespoons and use this honey mustard sauce to marinate the salmon for at least 30 min to an hour.  Instead of dry bread crumbs, try using shake and bake flavors.  I like the cajun mix but use whatever suits your tastebuds.  I would definitely use more parsley and finely diced.  Pecans are terrific and you should not skip out on it since it adds a great nutty flavor.  Make these changes and you'll definitely increase the flavor.
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2009-02-04T12:12:42.08
helpfulCount:
0

My husband and I thought this recipe is fantastic!  For those who thought that there wasn't enough flavor, there are "bold and spicy" or other varieties of dijon mustard that might oomph it up.  I'm not a huge fan of mustard, so I used equal amounts of dijon mustard and honey, and it was perfect for me.  Thanks for sharing this recipe!

text:
Got a nice fresh Coho Salmon steak and decided to use this recipe. Followed it to a T and were very pleased with the outcome. We also used this on Tillapia fillets and our kids really eat them up. Even our picky eater ate the whole fillet. I like my fish very rare, my wife like it medium so we found that the cooking directions were perfect for rare fish. If you like it more done you may have to cook it longer. You may also want to try broiling it.

I look forward to having this again!

text:
This recipe was very, very good. I used a good dijon mustard and raw honey, and pasted it on rather thickly instead of just brushing it on. I also used crushed almonds instead of pecans since I didn't have any, which turned out fine. The end result was flavorful and tasty, and blended well with the oiliness of the salmon. Even my picky husband who doesn't like strong fish liked this dish. I'll be making it again!

text:
This was easy and very tasty.  I probably went a little heavy on the honey, so next time, I will try harder to get the 2 to 1 ratio of mustard to honey.  I also spread on the mixture, then poured on the crumb/pecans.  I finished it under the broiler, but did not keep an eye on it, so I scraped off a thin layer of the crumbs that were a bit dark (black)and it was still delicious.  I used italian breadcrumbs, cause I didn't have plain and left out the parsley.  Will definitely make again.

text:
Everyone loved this! No wonder the reviews are so good, this is easy and tasty. Our honey had crystalized in the jar, and was very thick (we shouldn't have bought such a large bottle of it). I used it anyway (and found out online that it's OK to use). The thick honey actually helped, made the sauce thicker and it stuck well to the fish. Instead of brushing the sauce on, I used a spatula to spread it on like a paste - worked great.

I made this recipe by the book but I didn't really like it even though my bf loved it.. so I decided to change a few things after getting some ideas from the reviews here. I didn't use any breadcrumbs and changed the pecans to walnuts(so 1/2 cup walnuts) and I also used 1/2 dijon mustard and 1/2 horseradish mustard. After changing those things, it turned out perfect and was divine! And the good thing is my bf still loves it! I eat this with steamed buttered-asparagus.. Yum!

text:
Wow, this was by far one of the best reviewed dinners I have ever made! I doubled the dijon and honey and used garlic & herb bread crumbs; instead of "lightly brushing" the fillets in the mustard mix I used my hands to thoroughly coat them in the honey  mustard and then the bread crumbs/parsley (left out the nuts.) The result was a nicely breaded salmon fillet that was crunchy on the outside and moist and delicious on the outside. I served it with some rice and the broccoli w/garlic sauce that's on this site. My family loved it - will definitely make again and again (and again!)

This recipe leaves something to be desired. I found it to be just ok..nothing special. It did turn out very moist..the only thing the recipe has going for it. I didn't think the dijon did any favors for this recipe. The breading gets very soggy, and it needs a serious flavor kick in the gills. text:
This was pretty tasty for baked salmon.  I usually make mine on the grill so this was a nice alternative.  I didn't have any pecans so I used pistachios instead and generously brushed on the mustard mixture on the salmon then added the crumb/nut mixture and then poured the rest of the mustard over that.  I needed to bake for more like 20 minutes since I had a thicker cut.  Next time I just might cut down on the honey a tad bit or just buy the honey dijon mustard that is already mixed in a jar.  Was just a hint too sweet and that overpowered the mustard taste I love with my salmon.

text:
YUMMY and EASY!  I grill or sautee salmon steaks often.  This week it just seemed like so much work (especially keeping my toddler out of the way and busy while frying).  I hopped on to allrecipes and discovered this wonderful recipe.  I had everything I needed on hand! (I used tarragon mustardand I had one whole salmon fillet).  I had to double the baking time because of the size of my fish.
Popping this in the oven and being able to enterain my toddler in the kitchen without worrying about fat splatters opened up a whole new world of salmon-steak-cooking for me.  I loved it, DH loved it, and, most importantly, 2-yr-old DS loved it.  Thank you for making a tasty recipe that is easy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I must admit..I was very skeptical of this recipe before I tried it.  I was pretty impressed! The baking really mellow'd out the flavor of the sauce.  I was afraid it was going to be too mustardy/mayonaisey, but it was actually nice and light when it came out of the oven.

My substitutions:
No pecans, thought I had walnuts, but had to settle for peeled and sliver'd almonds, which i chopped on my cutting board

Used Brummel and Brown instead of butter

Used parsely flakes instead of the fresh kind.  I think next time i'm going to use about 5 or 6 t of flakes.

Used creamy grey pupon dijon instead of the standard kind.

region:

country:
None
text:
My husband exclaimed "Delicious!" My daughter and I both thought it was very good (though I still prefer hollandaise sauce on my salmon to this sauce). My son, however, did not care for it much and thought the sauce was too sweet and overpowered the flavor of the salmon. In his words, "salmon should taste like salmon".  The effect of the sauce can be controlled by the amount you brush on.  Next time I will try a lighter coating of the sauce.  It is a very easy and quick recipe to prepare.  I left out the bread crumbs since I didn't have any.  The pecans were a very nice touch.  I served it with a mushroom & herb couscous to which I added lemon juice and sauteed green onions & garlic.  Will definitely make again.  Thank you Arnie!

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe, but I think it's difficult to rate because its outcome is so variable depending on the quality of the fish and the strength of the mustard you use. For example, as I live in France and dijon mustard here is much stronger than it is in the US, i had to use more honey than recommended. Those of you who felt it was too fishy or that the sauce was too strong should really give it a second chance- you've just got to tweek the recipe according to the products you have available....

text:
I liked this recipe to the point that it mademe search more.  I found that I ddi not like the idea of adding all that butter to the dijon-honey sauce coating.  I tried this recipe again with some dijon mixed with a few dashes of pinot grigio wine and used that as the coating followed byb a light coating of seaseoned breadcrumbs and then drizzled lightly with some olive oil.  Also, I baked the filet at 400 degrees F for 10 minutes to be able to still have a juicy, tender filet.  I also omitted the pecans the second time.

text:
This is one of the easiest, best salmon recipes I've ever made. I suggest using Dry Italian Bread Crumbs, which are finer. This will give the salmon a little more of a crust. It also absorbs the honey/mustard mixture better. You can also use Honey Mustard instead of Dijon, and it still turns out excellent.

I read many of the other reviews and made the following adjustments and found the salmon perfect:  3/4 cup butter, about 5 tablespoons of honey dijon mustard, 1/2 cup bread crumbs, and no pecans.  Marinate the salmon for at least 30 minutes.  Took about 22 minutes.  Great!
